item.title: Amsterdam Officials Plan Makeover of ‘Black Pete’ Holiday Character
item.description: Black Pete, featured prominently in holiday celebrations as the Moorish servant of St. Nicholas and portrayed in blackface, will change appearance to become Sooty Pete.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE
item.media:description: Black Pete at Amsterdam's Sinterklaas (Santa Claus) parade in 2013. The city's mayor said the character would change in appearance over the next four years to make him less of an offensive racial stereotype.

item.title: Letter From the Mideast: Gaza Conflict Is Just the Latest Round in a Long War
item.description: Israel’s real problem is the instability from the failure to negotiate a sovereign Palestinian state and finally fix its borders.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian boys holding Hamas flags stood amid the rubble of a destroyed mosque in Gaza on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Newspaper Prints Fake Obituary of Rival’s Owner
item.description: A full-page obituary in the Chinese-language Oriental Daily claimed that the owner of a rival newspaper, Apple Daily, had died.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: The media tycoon Jimmy Lai at his company's headquarters in Hong Kong in 2011.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Celebrity Drug Cases, Industry Signs Deal in Beijing
item.description: Forty-two artist management agencies in Beijing have signed an agreement with the police vowing to take action against illegal drug use within the industry, a newspaper has reported.
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: The actor Gao Hu is the latest celebrity to be caught up in a crackdown on drugs.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: More Churches Lose Their Crosses Despite Protests
item.description: The police have cut down the cross from atop Salvation Church in Wenzhou, witnesses say, ending a weekslong standoff with parishioners.
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: Officials in Wenzhou used a crane to remove a cross from atop Salvation Church in Wenzhou on Thursday. The operation is shown in a photo provided by a member of a nearby church congregation.

item.title: In South Korea, Pope Francis Offers Consolation and Hope
item.description: In the first papal visit to Asia since 1999, the pope also met with South Koreans who lost relatives in a ferry disaster in April.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Pope Francis met with President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, right, in Seoul on Thursday.

item.title: At Least 10 Injured After Police Fire on Tibetan Protesters
item.description: The shootings took place on Tuesday, after Tibetans had gathered to protest the detention the previous day of a respected village leader.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Russian Convoy Rolling Again Toward Ukraine
item.description: Around 250 commercial and army trucks left a military base in Russia heading south, but their intended destination remained unclear.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: A convoy of trucks resumed its journey on Thursday from a military base in the city of Voronezh.

item.title: Mubarak Tells Court He Gave All For Egypt
item.description: In his first public statement since his ouster, former President Hosni Mubarak recited the achievements of what he called a 62-year career of service to Egypt.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt was transported by helicopter and ambulance for a court appearance on Wednesday.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Egypt’s Fondness for Foreigners
item.description: Most Egyptians are anything but xenophobic. It’s the autocrats who are to blame.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAA AL ASWANY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: After Erdogan, Turkey’s Future Will Be Liberal
item.description: Erdogan won on Sunday, but the era of Islamist dominance is ending. Today's young Turks want real democracy.
item.dc:creator: By SONER CAGAPTAY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Learning to Forget Tibet in China
item.description: In the process of assimilation, my Tibetan past was nearly rubbed out. Just like Beijing wanted.
item.dc:creator: By TSERING WOESER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Family of Dissident Lawyer Fears for His Health After Prison
item.description: Gao Zhisheng, who was released from prison last week, is suffering from malnutrition and psychological problems as a result of his years of incarceration, an advocacy group said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Gao Zhisheng, in Beijing on Apr. 7, 2010.

item.title: By Sea and by Ladder, Africans Seek Entry to Spain
item.description: Migrants from Africa continued to pour across the Mediterranean this week, and Spain’s sea rescue service picked up 681 people traveling in 70 small boats across the Strait of Gibraltar.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A Red Cross worker in the Spanish port of Tarifa.

item.title: New to the Archaeologist’s Tool Kit: The Drone
item.description: A drone air force has been created to map, monitor and safeguard Peru’s many endangered archaeological sites.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and RALPH BLUMENTHAL
item.media:credit: The Ministry of Culture of Peru
item.media:description: Drones help create 3-D images like the one of Inka Wasi, an Incan palace.

item.title: Pope Begins Visit to South Korea
item.description: Pope Francis arrived on Thursday for the first papal visit to the country in a quarter century.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Taking Break From Crises Elsewhere, Kerry Turns to Asia and Pacific
item.description: The Obama administration’s goal of rebalancing American foreign policy to emphasize the region has taken a back seat lately, but Secretary of State John Kerry sought, for the moment, to change that.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry as he left Australia on Wednesday before going on to Hawaii.

item.title: Militants’ Siege on Mountain in Iraq Is Over, Pentagon Says
item.description: Defense officials said that American airstrikes and Kurdish fighters had broken the Islamic militants’ siege of Mount Sinjar, allowing thousands of the Yazidis trapped there to escape.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Displaced Yazidis crossing the Iraqi-Syrian border at the Fishkhabur crossing, in northern Iraq, on Wednesday. Thousands who had been besieged have escaped.

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Lawmaker Punished in Scandal
item.description: Mexico’s conservative opposition party has removed one of its congressional whips after a video emerged showing him and other legislators at a party with table dancers.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Vote Aims to Eliminate Militias
item.description: Parliament voted Wednesday to disband the country’s militias and called on the United Nations to protect civilians in an effort to end the worst fighting among armed factions since the 2011 fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Indonesia: 2 Held in American’s Death
item.description: The body of a Chicago-area woman has been found stuffed into a suitcase on Bali, and her daughter and the daughter’s boyfriend are being held in her death.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: For U.N. Leader on Human Rights, Finish Line Looks Blurry
item.description: Known for her bluntness, Navi Pillay held the post of United Nations high commissioner for human rights longer than any of her predecessors.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:credit: United Nations Mission in South Sudan, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Navi Pillay, center, the United Nations’ top human rights official, meeting in South Sudan with a rebel leader, Riek Machar, right.

item.title: France Plans to Ship Arms to Embattled Kurdish Forces in Iraq
item.description: President François Hollande said the deliveries were in response to “urgent” appeals from the Kurds. Britain also announced nonlethal aid deliveries.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY and ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Yazidi ethnic minority, fleeing the advance of Sunni militants, enter Iraq from Syria on Sunday.

item.title: Saudis Give $100 Million to U.N. Fight on Terrorism
item.description: A large gift to the United Nations Counter-Terrorism Center as Islamist militant extremism hits ever closer to home.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Rocket Fire Casts Doubt on Truce in Gaza
item.description: The new exchanges between Israel and elements in Gaza marred an agreement to extend a cease-fire for another five days.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and JODI RUDOREN
